WASHINGTON The U.S. Senate this month will debate legislation that passed overwhelmingly in the House of Representatives and aims to give Puerto Rico some relief from its $70 billion debt
column2: Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell said on Tuesday.McConnell's announcement came after some House members briefed fellow Republicans in the Senate on the content of the legislation
column3: which would establish a federal oversight board to restructure Puerto Rican debt.Backers of the House-passed bill are hoping the Senate signs off on the legislation before July 1
column4: when Puerto Rico faces a deadline on a $1.9 billion debt payment.Representative Rob Bishop
column5: who chairs the House Natural Resources Committee
column6: which steered the legislation through that chamber
column7: told reporters that Republican senators peppered him with questions about the makeup of the oversight board and its powers. He added that he assured senators the bill is not a taxpayer bailout of Puerto Rico and that it would not have an impact on U.S. states.Puerto Rico is a U.S. territory and some critics of the bill have expressed concerns that a control board appointed by Washington might not have the Caribbean island's best interests in mind.The legislation also got a boost
column9: on Tuesday when Senate Finance Committee Chairman Orrin Hatch offered qualified support for the House bill. He added that he was considering offering changes to the bill but did not elaborate.

column1: Hatch's Finance Committee has oversight of the Puerto Rico debt legislation.Some Senate Democrats also have expressed reservations with the bill and indicated that they could seek amendments
column2: but it was not clear if they actually would.Any changes made by the Senate to the House-passed bill would send it back to the House to accept
column3: reject or make further amendments.

column1: Bishop left open the possibility of July 1 arriving with Congress still working on the Puerto Rico bill.""It's not the end of the world
column2: Bishop said of the possibility of Congress putting finishing touches on legislation into July.

column1: Market forces
column2: as long as they realize we're moving forward to a solution and we're close to it
column3: I think that would mitigate against anything that would be negative that would impact the entire market
column4: Bishop added.The Obama administration has voiced its support for the House bill
column7: which suffers from a poverty rate of around 45 percent
column8: has been hobbled by its worsening debt problems
column9: with some schools and medical facilities closing and island residents fleeing to the mainland United States where many find jobs
column10: primarily in central Florida. (Reporting By Richard Cowan; Editing by David Gregorio and Dan Grebler)"	['Obama'

By Letitia Stein and Jarrett Renshaw

column1: ORLANDO
column2: Fla. Orlando nightclub killer Omar Mateen had expressed sympathy for a variety of Islamist extremists
column3: including groups in the Middle East that are sworn enemies
column5: as a picture began to emerge of the angry
column6: violent man who carried out America's deadliest mass shooting.U.S. authorities said they had found no direct links between Islamic State and Mateen
column7: the U.S.-born son of Afghan immigrants who killed 49 people at a gay nightclub in Orlando on Sunday.       Mateen
column9: was shot dead by police who stormed the Pulse club with armored cars after a three-hour siege. In 911 calls during his rampage
column10: the killer expressed allegiance to Islamic State leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi.    But Federal Bureau of Investigation Director James Comey said Mateen had made comments favorable to multiple armed Islamist movements and people
column11: which ""adds a little bit to the confusion about his motives."" President Barack Obama said Mateen was likely a homegrown extremist. ""So far
column12: we see no indication that this was a plot directed from outside the United States and we see no indication that he was part of any kind of network
column13: Comey told reporters in Washington. ""We're highly confident this killer was radicalized at least in some part through the internet.""    Islamic State
column14: which controls territory in Iraq and Syria
column15: reiterated on Monday a claim of responsibility
column16: although it offered no signs to indicate coordination with the gunman.        In calls to authorities on Sunday
column17: Mateen also mentioned support for the Boston Marathon bombers and a Florida man who became a Nusra Front suicide bomber in Syria
column18: Comey said. Nusra is an al Qaeda offshoot which is at odds with Islamic State in Syria's civil war.        Co-workers reported Mateen to the FBI in 2013 after he had made ""inflammatory and contradictory"" statements
column19: including a claim that he had family connections to al Qaeda and membership of Shi'ite militant group Hezbollah
column20: a bitter rival.The FBI's Miami office investigated Mateen for 10 months and interviewed him twice but found no evidence of a crime or connection with a militant group. Comey said the FBI was also ""working to understand what role anti-gay bigotry may have played"" in the attack. The massacre reverberated on the presidential campaign trail
column21: where Republican Donald Trump and Democrat Hillary Clinton
column22: the two likely opponents in the Nov. 8 election
column23: clashed over how to confront violent Islamist extremists.    Trump proposed suspending immigration to the United States from countries with a history of terrorism against America
column25: while Clinton warned against demonizing Muslims and called for tougher gun safety measures.Obama is to visit Orlando on Thursday to pay respects to families of the victims.'NEEDLES IN NATIONWIDE HAYSTACK'

column1: The Orlando killings followed the massacre of 14 people in San Bernardino
column2: California
column3: last year and raised the question of whether the United States will have to confront jihadist attacks in the homeland for years to come. Comey said tracking apparent lone wolf attackers like Mateen was like finding ""needles in a nationwide haystack"" while also trying to work out what kind of people could become radicalized.The Florida shooting spree began early on Sunday when the club was packed with some 350 revelers at a Latin music night. Many fled as the gunman raked the crowd with bullets from an AR-15-style semiautomatic rifle and a pistol.An initial wave of officers charged into the club and trapped Mateen in a bathroom
column4: Orlando Police Chief John Mina told reporters. That allowed many patrons to flee
column5: although others were trapped in the restroom with Mateen
column6: leading to a standoff.Police negotiated with Mateen for about three hours before breaking a hole in the wall
column7: which allowed hostages to escape.Mateen also emerged from the hole and was shot dead by officers
column8: police said.Some 53 people were wounded and 29 remain hospitalized at Orlando Regional Medical Center. Michael Cheatham
column9: chief trauma surgeon at the hospital
column10: told Fox News he expects all of the survivors in the hospital to survive.

column13: who worshipped at his mosque.    Mateen was an armed guard at a gated retirement community

column1: 4	4	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-convention-idUSKCN0Z029G	Cleveland sued over speech rights outside Republican convention	"
By Kim Palmer
| CLEVELAND
CLEVELAND Three groups planning to demonstrate at the Republican National Convention in July sued the city of Cleveland on Tuesday
column2: seeking immediate changes to security measures due to their ""unacceptable restrictions"" on free speech.Presumptive presidential nominee Donald Trump is expected to officially become the Republican Party's candidate for president at the July 18-21 convention
column3: which will attract protesters for various causes who plan to demonstrate outside.Trump campaign events have drawn large and raucous demonstrations
column4: some of which have resulted in clashes between the candidate's supporters and opponents.Led by the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU)
column5: the three groups filed suit in U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Ohio
column6: naming the city of Cleveland and Mayor Frank Jackson as defendants.

column1: Dan Williams
column2: a spokesman for the mayor
column3: said in a phone call he had not seen the lawsuit and that the city does not comment on ongoing litigation. He said the city and the ACLU have discussed protester rights and regulations in meetings.    The plaintiffs are Citizens for Trump
column4: a Texas-based group that supports the businessman's campaign; Organize Ohio
column5: a liberal activist group; and Northeast Ohio Coalition for the Homeless
column6: a charitable organization.The lawsuit contends that Cleveland has imposed an unnecessarily large restricted zone of 3.3 square miles (8.5 square km) in the city center where free speech and mobility will be limited.

column1: The limitations apply far beyond the part of the city where the convention activities will take place. ... These regulations severely limit the opportunities for members of the public to exercise their expressive rights during the convention
column2: the lawsuit said.The lawsuit seeks to reduce the size and regulations of the restricted an area and asks the court to immediately address the city's rules for issuing protest permits and what the ACLU called persistent delays in approving those permits.

column1: Many of these applications have been pending for months - some as long as four months. The city's continuing refusal to approve or deny these applications leaves the organizers of these activities in limbo
column2: the lawsuit said.Protesters need adequate time to make travel arrangements and rent needed materials such as portable toilets and sound stage equipment
column3: the ACLU has said. (Reporting by Kim Palmer in Cleveland and Daniel Trotta in New York; Editing by Richard Chang)"	['Palmer'
